message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Option (A) is not appropriate because the resident should explain the procedure, risks, and benefits before obtaining informed consent, not just have the patient sign a form. Option (B) is not correct because residents are legally allowed to obtain informed consent, but should only do so if they are knowledgeable about the procedure. Option (C) is incorrect because suprapubic catheterization is a valid option for patients who are unable to void and have failed transurethral catheterization. Option (D) is the most appropriate response because it acknowledges the resident’s lack of experience and defer to the urologist to obtain informed consent when she becomes available.
